title: ArcCirc Vision: Arctic Circular Economy Resource Centre
content:
üèîÔ∏è What if the Arctic had its own Circular Economy Resource Centre?

Cathrine Barth from Natural State posed this transformative question at Nordic Circular Summit 2025:

"How could it be if we go together and establish an ArcCirc?"

**ArcCirc - Arctic Circular Economy Resource Centre** - modeled on the EU CERC but focused on Arctic solidarity and collaboration.

The logic is compelling:

üîπ 4 million people live in the Arctic globally - "quite a large nation"
üîπ Arctic communities risk being "left in a linear lock-in" while the world transitions
üîπ EU programs are "complicated to apply, complicated to report" for small Arctic entities
üîπ The Arctic needs policy support, business development, and knowledge sharing adapted to Arctic contexts

As Sitra establishes EU CERC to engage with the Global South on critical materials partnerships, the Arctic - home to many of those critical materials - deserves coordinated circular support.

This isn't about the Arctic as passive recipient. It's about the Arctic as active partner in designing circular futures.

"Every material comes from somewhere and is going to live possibly forever," Barth noted. Material economics, material rights, material ownership - these newborn concepts connect us all.

ArcCirc could provide:
‚Üí Arctic-adapted policy frameworks
‚Üí Business development for local circular enterprises
‚Üí Indigenous knowledge integration
‚Üí Regional collaboration mechanisms
‚Üí Voice and agency for 4 million Arctic residents

The vision was spontaneous, bold, and immediately compelling.

Is the Nordic-Arctic region ready to make ArcCirc a reality?

title: Circularity as Security Strategy
content:
üíé "Circularity is no longer an environmental agenda. It is now a matter of competitiveness and security."

‚Äî Mika Sulkinoja, Sitra, at #NordicCircularSummit

This is the fundamental reframing of our time.

When Europe:
‚Üí Depends on China for critical materials
‚Üí Exports the very materials it needs most (black mass from batteries)
‚Üí Sets recycling targets it can't meet
‚Üí Faces export restrictions on graphite, rare earths, and lithium

Circular economy is no longer about being "green." It's about strategic autonomy.

The EU Critical Raw Materials Act sets ambitious 2030 targets:
üéØ 10% extraction within EU
üéØ 40% processing within EU
üéØ 25% recycling within EU

But here's the catch: "We cannot mine our way out of this dependency."

We need BOTH responsible mining AND circularity. But circularity must define the long-term path.

Europe's remanufacturing market could grow from ‚Ç¨31B to ‚Ç¨100B by 2030, creating 500,000 jobs. That's not environmental charity - that's economic resilience.

The strongest benefits come from INNER LOOPS:
‚úÖ Reuse
‚úÖ Repair
‚úÖ Refurbishment
‚úÖ Remanufacturing

Recycling is essential - but it's the LAST loop, not the first.

When supply chains tighten and geopolitical tensions rise, circular economy shifts from nice-to-have to strategic imperative.

Is your organization treating circularity as a security strategy?

title: The Investment Gap: From Why to How
content:
üí∞ THE CIRCULAR INVESTMENT GAP - And Why It's Actually Good News

At Nordic Circular Summit, Anders Ladefoged from the European Economic and Social Committee shared a remarkable shift:

Companies are no longer asking "WHY circular economy?"

They're asking "HOW do we implement it?"

This is transformative. But the gap between intent and execution is massive.

**THE ANALYSIS**

EESC + Boston Consulting Group analyzed what it takes for Europe to become sustainable in transport, energy, and circularity.

Conclusion: "Not only regulatory deficiencies, but an INVESTMENT GAP that is huge."

**WHAT INDUSTRY IS CALLING FOR**

The resulting recommendations were "actually quite far-reaching":

üîπ Off-take guarantees
üîπ Floor prices
üîπ More public procurement
üîπ Binding requirements for recycled content

**THE SIGNAL**

"When companies start calling for things like this, it means they are ON BOARD," Ladefoged noted.

Danish industry companies endorsed these calls. They're not resisting regulation - they're demanding STRONGER, MORE PREDICTABLE policy frameworks that create investable markets.

**THE FINANCE PERSPECTIVE**

Luca De Lorenzo from Nordic Investment Bank added the economic foundation:

"Money goes where value is created. It's as simple as that."

The game-changer? "The value of resilience has increased. This is structural."

When supply chain resilience becomes monetizable, circular business models that seemed uneconomical suddenly make financial sense.

"Shortening supply chains has a value. And we can put a dollar or euro sign or kroner sign to it."

**CONCRETE EXAMPLES**

‚Üí FERC Denmark: Food-grade plastic recycling with design integration
‚Üí OtoKumpu: Green steel with 70% scrap content
‚Üí ‚Ç¨45B Nordic Investment Bank balance sheet backing circular transitions

**THE STRUCTURAL SHIFT**

10-15 years ago: optimize supply chains purely on cost.
Today: "The fundamental trust in the market is broken."

Resilience, autonomy, and shorter supply chains now have quantifiable value - and that's permanent, not temporary.

"These businesses, these type of solutions, suddenly become much more interesting to finance."

**THE PATH FORWARD**

Investment gap is real. But the shift from "why" to "how" - and industry CALLING for regulation - signals we've crossed a threshold.

The business case for circularity is no longer theoretical. It's structural.

Is your organization ready to close the implementation gap?

title: Indigenous Rights and the Critical Minerals Scramble
content:
üåç INDIGENOUS RIGHTS IN THE CRITICAL MINERALS SCRAMBLE

As demand for battery metals accelerates, one of the most critical questions facing Europe was posed at Nordic Circular Summit:

"Can we maintain Free Prior Informed Consent? Are we able to pay a higher price?"

Patrick Schroeder from Chatham House answered his own question:

**"We have to."**

**THE CONTEXT**

‚Üí 80% of world's biodiversity is in indigenous-stewarded lands
‚Üí Critical minerals often located in indigenous territories (S√°pmi, Greenland)
‚Üí FPIC inadequately applied for 20-30 years across the board
‚Üí Growing risk of "race to the bottom" as scramble for minerals intensifies

**THE COMPETITIVE PRESSURE**

US companies (especially under recent administration shifts), Chinese mining companies, and Middle Eastern investors "do not look at ESG or indigenous rights."

This creates immense pressure on European companies to cut corners to remain competitive.

**EUROPE'S CHOICE**

"We need to do this despite the international pressure that we might have," Schroeder affirmed.

Maintaining FPIC and ESG standards is not optional - it's a moral and strategic imperative.

**VALUE REDISTRIBUTION**

Luca De Lorenzo from Nordic Investment Bank emphasized two principles:

1. **Value Redistribution**: "If you do transition, there should be value creation. What is important is redistribution of that value creation. It shouldn't only go to the project or corporate - there must be a good mechanism to redistribute that value."

2. **Mutual Accountability**: Communities must be part of the value creation AND understand the broader context and need for change.

**DIALOGUE AS OPPORTUNITY**

Anders Ladefoged reframed indigenous consultation:

"This dialogue is not just something that should be seen as an obligation, it should also be seen as an OPPORTUNITY."

Why? "The decisions that are made and the solutions that are implemented will be BETTER if they involve input from the people who actually live and work in the Arctic."

4 million people globally live and work in the Arctic. They all have visions for how their local environment could be improved, what jobs they want, what facilities they need.

"If you talk to these people" rather than imposing "ready-made solutions top-down," you get genuine partnership.

**THE INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGE ADVANTAGE**

Schroeder shared how UNEP's Global Environment Outlook brought indigenous representatives into scientific assessments - their traditional knowledge "changed many of the discussions."

This isn't charity. It's practical wisdom that improves outcomes.

**THE BOTTOM LINE**

Europe faces a choice:
‚Üí Race to the bottom on indigenous rights to compete
‚Üí Maintain high standards and build just, resilient partnerships

The Nordic Circular Summit speakers were unequivocal: maintain standards, redistribute value, engage in genuine dialogue.

Because it's only through inclusiveness and well-functioning societies that we get long-term sustainable change.

How is your organization approaching indigenous rights in material sourcing?

title: Arctic Solidarity: The ArcCirc Vision
content:
üèîÔ∏è ARCTIC SOLIDARITY: Why 4 Million People Deserve a Circular Future

Cathrine Barth from Natural State posed a transformative question at Nordic Circular Summit:

"How could it be if we go together and establish an ArcCirc?"

**What is ArcCirc?**
Arctic Circular Economy Resource Centre - modeled on EU CERC but focused on Arctic collaboration.

**Why It Matters:**

üîπ 4 million people live in the Arctic - "quite a large nation" (larger than many EU member states!)

üîπ Risk of being "left in a linear lock-in" while the world transitions to circularity

üîπ EU programs "complicated to apply, complicated to report" for small Arctic entities

üîπ Arctic home to critical materials needed for global transition

üîπ Indigenous knowledge essential for sustainable development

**What ArcCirc Could Provide:**

‚Üí Policy frameworks adapted to Arctic contexts
‚Üí Business development for local circular enterprises
‚Üí Indigenous rights integration and FPIC
‚Üí Regional collaboration mechanisms
‚Üí Knowledge sharing among Arctic communities
‚Üí Voice and agency for Arctic residents

**The Vision:**

This isn't about the Arctic as passive recipient of policies designed in Brussels or Helsinki.

It's about the Arctic as ACTIVE PARTNER in designing circular futures.

"Every material comes from somewhere and is going to live possibly forever," Barth noted.

Material economics. Material rights. Material ownership.

These concepts connect us all - and the Arctic must be at the table.

As Sitra establishes EU CERC to engage with the Global South, the Arctic deserves coordinated circular support.

**Anders Ladefoged's reminder:**
"This dialogue is not just an obligation - it's an OPPORTUNITY. The solutions will be BETTER if they involve input from people who live and work in the Arctic."

4 million people. Vast resources. Traditional knowledge. Climate vulnerability.

The Arctic isn't a marginal concern. It's central to materialising a just and resilient circular future.

Is the Nordic-Arctic region ready to make ArcCirc a reality?

title: Material Economics: A New Reality
content:
üì± MATERIAL ECONOMICS: Understanding the New Reality

Cathrine Barth introduced a concept that's reshaping how we think about resources:

"Every material comes from somewhere and is going to live possibly forever."

Welcome to material economics. üîÑ

**What is Material Economics?**

The Digital Product Passport (DPP) makes visible what's been invisible:
‚Üí Where materials come from
‚Üí How they move through the economy
‚Üí Who owns them at each stage
‚Üí How long they persist

**Key Concepts:**

üîπ Material Journeys: Tracking materials over decades and centuries
üîπ Material Rights: Who has agency over materials?
üîπ Material Ownership: Beyond product ownership to material stewardship
üîπ Material Independence: Security through circular material flows

**Why It Matters:**

Traditional economics treats materials as:
‚ùå Inputs to extract
‚ùå Throughput to process
‚ùå Waste to dispose

Material economics treats materials as:
‚úÖ Permanent economic actors
‚úÖ Assets to steward
‚úÖ Resources that "live possibly forever"

**The ESPR Framework:**

EU's Ecodesign for Sustainable Products Regulation sets requirements for:
‚Üí Durability
‚Üí Repairability
‚Üí Upgradability
‚Üí Recyclability
‚Üí Digital Product Passports

**The Inner Loops Priority:**

Europe's remanufacturing market: ‚Ç¨31B ‚Üí ‚Ç¨100B by 2030

Because keeping materials in use (reuse, repair, refurbishment) > recycling.

Recycling is the LAST loop, not the first.

**Mika Sulkinoja's insight:**
"The strongest economic and social benefits come from the inner loops: reuse, repair, refurbishment and remanufacturing."

**The Security Dimension:**

"Circularity is no longer environmental - it's competitiveness and security."

When Europe depends on China for critical materials, material independence becomes strategic imperative.

**The Arctic Context:**

Arctic holds critical minerals needed for global transition.

Material economics must include:
‚Üí Indigenous stewardship (80% of biodiversity in indigenous lands)
‚Üí Value redistribution
‚Üí Free Prior Informed Consent
‚Üí Arctic-adapted frameworks

Cathrine's note: These are "newborn topics." We must be "a little bit clumsy, a little bit forgiving" as we learn.

But they CONNECT us - across borders, generations, and economic systems.

Welcome to the material economics era.
